course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory I
course.description: This is the laboratory course designed for students who enrolled in CHEM 2110 Organic Chemistry l and CHEM 2210 Inorganic Chemistry I. It includes a series of organic and inorganic experiments related to the theory learnt in the lecture courses. Students will be trained to perform a wide range of basic synthetic chemistry laboratory techniques, operate chemical instruments in laboratory, relate the physical and chemical principles and theory in practice and develop their data interpretation and analyzing skills. For CHEM students only.
course.corequisites: CHEM 2110 AND CHEM 2210
course.exclusions: CHEM 2150, CHEM 2155, CHEM 2250

reviews.author: Linda y
reviews.comment_content:
1 Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC)
2 Re crystallization & Melting Point Measurement
3 Separation of Chemical Components from a Mixture
4. Organic Synthesis :Williamson Ether Synthesis)
5. Synthesis of Metal Chelate Complexes  


Intended Learning Outcomes

1 Describe the fundamentals of organic and inorganic chemistry.
2 Assess and manage the risks of organic and inorganic chemical substances and
laboratory procedures.
3 Conduct analysis and interpretation of experimental data of synthetic chemistry.
4 Conduct standard laboratory procedures involved in fundamental chemical synthesis
and instrumental work.
5 Operate a range of chemical instrumentation.
6 Work independently and collaborate in team work.
reviews.comment_teaching: the tutorial is very important, make sure you study well before experimenting. It is very helpful for to your lab quiz.

reviews.author: Sonic12
reviews.title: Review of CHEM2550
reviews.comment_content:
Expt 1. Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC)
Expt 2. Recrystallization & Melting Point Measurement
Expt 3. Separation of Chemical Components From a Mixture
Expt 4. Organic Synthesis (Williamson Ether Synthesis) & IR Spectroscopy
Expt 5. Synthesis of Metal Chelate Complexes & UV-Vis Spectroscopy

Almost related to organic chemistry contents. Only the last experiment was about inorganic. Actually, some contents are highly related to that of organic chemistry II.

As many students enroll in this course while attending the organic I lecture, you might need to study extra things that will show up in the following spring semester organic II. (ex. IR spec)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Fair, overall.
Most of the teaching was done by Prof. Veronica and TAs. They are helpful and keen to answer your questions.

One tip is that it might be helpful for you to ask about the experiment report grading scheme because these so-called "terms & conditions" for getting the full mark are quite harsh and condition-specific.

Also, if you have any doubts about the lab quiz grade, ask Prof. Veronica. She might give you some extra marks back if you're logic is reasonable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance & Punctuality (6%)
Risk Assessment (5%)
Lab Quizzes (20%)
Performance in Laboratory (25%)
Product/Results (10%)
Lab Reports (35%)

Lab quizzes and lab reports will be crucial factors for the grade difference. For other things, everyone almost gets full marks.

Lab quizzes are somewhat difficult so pay attention to the lab manuals and uploaded videos. The devil is in the detail.

As long as you perform the experiments well and follow the "guideline for lab report writing" your grades should be fine. But be warned, they deduct your mark even for minor things.

-Experiment 1-
Quiz: 20/20, mean: 12.7
Performance: 25/25, mean: 25
Product: 8.5/10, mean: 9.1
Risk Assessment: 5/5, mean: 5
Attendance: 5/5, mean: 5
Report: 26.06/35, mean: 27.5

-Experiment 2-
Quiz: 17/20, mean: 9.7
Performance: 25/25, mean: 25
Product: 10/10, mean: 9.6
Risk Assessment: 5/5, mean: 4.9
Attendance: 5/5, mean: 5
Report: 32.5/35, mean: 29.7

-Experiment 3-
Quiz: 14/20, mean: 9
Performance: 25/25, mean: 24.8
Product: 9/10, mean: 9.5
Risk Assessment: 5/5, mean: 5
Attendance: 5/5, mean: 5
Report: 33.5/35, mean: 30.4

-Experiment 4-
Quiz: 18/20, mean: 10.6
Performance: 25/25, mean: 24.9
Product: 10/10, mean: 8.1
Risk Assessment: 5/5, mean: 5
Attendance: 5/5, mean: 5
Report: 35/35, mean: 29.7

-Experiment 5-
Quiz: 20/20, mean: not released
Performance: 25/25, mean: 24.8
Product: 10/10, mean: 10
Risk Assessment: 5/5, mean: 5
Attendance: 5/5, mean: 5
Report: 35/35, mean: 29.7

Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
You need to read lab manuals and watch several experiment videos before doing the experiments.

The purpose of doing this is all about the lab quizzes not performing the experiment itself. The videos are somewhat long but just sparing some time for the day before the experiment would be enough.

For the report, you MUST read the document called the "guideline for lab report writing" and check whether you missed some critical points. This is very important for you to get a full mark and not lose points in a ridiculous way. (The reason why I'm saying "ridiculous" is that their reasons for deducting marks are many times absurd. Believe me.)
